Hi Magnus,

Yes, you're right of course that we need to traverse the network to
update bits whenever we add a node or a connection, so it's a case of
summing up the pros and cons to see if we get an overall performance
benefit.

Potentially we can avoid proper traversal (following the chain of
connections) in some cases by simply using the bitmaps. E.g. if we
make a new connection A->B, then we do:

1) 'A' and it's ancestor nodes need to be added to B's Ancestor list.
B can just copy across the bits from A it doesn't have set (e.g.
bitwise OR in 32bit chunks).
2) All of B's descendant nodes need to be updated in a similar manner
(bitwise OR). However, instead of following connections we can just
loop over a flat list of all nodes and update the ones that currently
have B as an ancestor.

Also, I haven't really thought about whether the whole scheme works
out better if we use bitmaps of descendants (D-lists) instead of
ancestors.

Colin.
